author: By Steven Lee Myers, Keith Bradsher and Tariq Panja
title: China’s Games: How Xi Jinping Is Staging the Olympics on His Terms
description: From Beijing’s unexpected bid through the coronavirus pandemic, China has managed to fulfill its promises and cow its critics.
content: When the International Olympic Committee met seven years ago to choose a host for the 2022 Winter Games, China’s leader, Xi Jinping, sent a short video message that helped tip the scale in a close, controversial vote.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tish Harrison Warren
title: The Systemic Realities Created by Legal Abortion
description: Thoughts on the 49th anniversary of Roe v. Wade.
content: One thing that I appreciate about the political left is that it often does a better job than the right of understanding how systems and culture shape personal choices. Conservatives, for instance, tend to see poverty largely as a result of poor life choices, and liberals tend to understand that factors such as systemic discrimination, inequality and lack of educational opportunities strongly contribute to economic insecurity. It’s not that personal choices don’t matter, but systemic realities cut off certain choices and make others far easier. The left generally understands that choice doesn’t happen in a vacuum and that external factors, including culture and law, shape people, the choices available to them and what they find moral, practical or even possible.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Yuhas
title: English Island Seeks a Landlord-King Who Likes Solitude, Seals and Beer
description: On Piel Island, winters are wet, travel is limited, and the solitary pub crowns the landlord king or queen under a shower of beer.
content: Overseeing a small island dominated by a castle, seals and a pub, an English council is searching for a new king or queen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: The Noise From Downstairs Is Terrible. Should I Sue the Landlord?
description: You have a right to the quiet enjoyment of your home, but lawsuits come with their own headaches. And there’s always room for negotiation.
content: Q: Last August, a dog day care opened in the retail space below my Williamsburg, Brooklyn rental apartment. Since then, I have endured intolerable noise from barking dogs from 6 a.m. to 8 p.m., while I work from home. I took videos and immediately complained to management. An attempt to soundproof the day care ceiling made things worse. For months, they promised to move me to another apartment, but that never materialized. With my lease ending next month, I asked for compensation for the mental toll this has taken on my well-being. They refused. What I can do?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch
title: Kohl’s Receives $9 Billion Offer Backed by Activist Investor
description: The offer comes as the retailer, like other brick-and-mortar stores, struggles with supply chain problems and competition from online sites.
content: The department store Kohl’s has received a roughly $9 billion offer to go private in a deal with an investment consortium backed by the activist hedge fund Starboard Value, according to two people familiar with the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan
title: The Olympic torch relay shrinks to ‘prioritize safety.’
description: The relay, usually global and lasting for months, will take place over just three days, be mostly local, and only select members of the public will be able to attend.
content: The Olympic torch’s public journey to the opening ceremony of the Winter Games will be much more lonely and with much less fanfare.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Harvey G. Stack, Leading Dealer in Rare Coins, Dies at 93
description: At the New York firm his father and uncle started in 1933, he was said to have personally conducted more auction sales than anyone else in the industry.
content: Harvey G. Stack, the patriarch of the family firm that bills itself as the nation’s largest rare coin business, died on Jan. 3 in New York. He was 93.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vjosa Isai
title: When Drake Is on Your Course Syllabus
description: The hip-hop star’s influence on Toronto has been enormous and now includes a Ryerson University course deconstructing him.
content: It’s the start of the winter term at Toronto’s Ryerson University, and most students are preparing for another semester of courses like mechanical engineering, economics and English literature. But 30 budding scholars will be studying what is perhaps a less traditional subject: the ins-and-outs of the hip-hop megastar Drake.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wilson
title: How a Calm Call for Help Led 2 N.Y.P.D. Officers Into a Hail of Gunfire
description: The latest deadly episode to rattle the city began with a routine domestic disturbance call and ended with one officer dead and another in critical condition.
content: The call came just a couple of hours into the police night tour on Friday, practically routine on a given evening in New York City. A mother said she was arguing with her son, who had verbally threatened her, and wanted officers to come to talk to him in their apartment in Harlem. Three officers — one who started last year, his partner with four years’ experience on the job and a rookie riding along to observe — pulled up outside the block of squat buildings and entered.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed O'Loughlin
title: ‘We need to sing again’: Ireland relaxes Covid restrictions.
description: Pubs and restaurants can return to regular hours, but face masks are still required in public spaces.
content: DUBLIN — Ireland cleared the way for its first full public celebration of St. Patrick’s Day in two years as the prime minister, Micheal Martin, announced on Friday that most Covid restrictions would end beginning on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith, Julie Bosman and Tracey Tully
title: Omicron Cases Appear to Peak in U.S., but Deaths Continue to Rise
description: The country is reporting upward of 700,000 new cases a day, fewer than earlier this month, but still far more than in any prior surge.
content: CHICAGO — New coronavirus cases have started to fall nationally, signaling that the Omicron-fueled spike that has infected tens of millions of Americans, packed hospitals and shattered records has finally begun to relent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Down Under, a Tennis Star Cheers for Her Family’s Buffalo Bills
description: When Buffalo plays Kansas City in their N.F.L. divisional playoff game, Jessica Pegula, whose parents own the Bills, hopes both she and the football team keep winning.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — As a Pittsburgh Steelers fan whose parents ended up buying the N.F.L.’s Buffalo Bills, Jessica Pegula has had to adapt. But she is in deep now, extolling the leadership virtues of quarterback Josh Allen even as she competes in the Australian Open tennis tournament, and taking the court in an outfit whose red, white and blue hues summon the Bills’ colors, thanks to her sponsor thinking ahead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: Judge Issues Stinging Free Speech Ruling Against University of Florida
description: While a lawsuit is being resolved, the university cannot bar professors from offering expert testimony in lawsuits against the state, the federal judge ruled.
content: WASHINGTON — A federal judge handed a crucial free-speech victory to six University of Florida professors Friday, ordering the university to stop enforcing a policy that had barred them from giving expert testimony in lawsuits against the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: N.F.L. Receivers Are Showcasing a Throwback Skill: Blocking
description: The run-pass option and screen-based offenses currently in favor in the N.F.L. rely on receivers who can throw blocks for their teammates.
content: N.F.L. wide receivers’ job descriptions are straightforward: Most of it is in the title.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Lisa Goddard, 55, Dies; Brought Climate Data to Those Who Needed It
description: She helped show government agencies around the world how to predict upcoming droughts, flooding and other extreme weather events.
content: Lisa Goddard, a climate scientist at Columbia University who harnessed cutting-edge computer models to bring invaluable data about upcoming floods, droughts and heat waves to people worldwide facing increasingly extreme weather events, died on Jan. 13 in Mount Kisco, N.Y. She was 55.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Passenger Exposed Buttocks and Threw a Can During Flight, Prosecutors Say
description: Shane McInerney, 29, was charged after his disruptive behavior aboard a flight from Dublin to John F. Kennedy International Airport on Jan. 7.
content: A passenger who refused to wear a mask on a flight from Dublin to New York pulled down his pants and exposed his buttocks, threw a can at a passenger and put his cap on the captain’s head and told him, “Don’t touch me,” prosecutors said in a case unsealed on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Gordon
title: How Meat Loaf Made a Cult Favorite: ‘Paradise by the Dashboard Light’
description: The eight-and-a-half minute tale of sexual awakening features drums by the E Street Band’s Max Weinberg and vocals from Ellen Foley, who help recount how the unlikely song came together.
content: The singer Meat Loaf, who died on Thursday, was a rock ’n’ roll anomaly: a portly force of nature whose theatrical musicality made him an unlikely but undeniable radio staple, and a standout presence in films like “The Rocky Horror Picture Show” and “Fight Club.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below, along with some solving tips and tricks by Wordplay’s own Deb Amlen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Graham and Adam Goldman
title: As F.B.I. Breached Texas Synagogue, Hostages Were Dashing for Exit
description: The federal agency said it was unaware that three hostages were already escaping the temple as an elite rescue team entered from different sides, killing the attacker.
content: COLLEYVILLE, Texas — Eleven hours into the standoff in a synagogue in suburban Fort Worth on Saturday evening, it was clear to the F.B.I. that the situation was devolving. The attacker, who had entered Congregation Beth Israel that morning and taken four hostages, was becoming more agitated and less communicative.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: Joe Manchin Thinks James Madison Is on His Side. Nope.
description: Arguments about the filibuster need the right context.
content: On Wednesday, Senate Democrats finally held their formal debate over ending (or at least amending) the filibuster to pass a new voting rights bill. Joe Manchin of West Virginia, a steadfast defender of the filibuster, repeated his case for keeping the rule, which in its current incarnation allows for unlimited debate on select forms of legislation barring 60 votes to end it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Robbins
title: The F.D.A. expands its approval of remdesivir to patients who are not hospitalized.
description: The treatment must be given via intravenous infusion over three consecutive days, generally at a hospital or clinic.
content: The Food and Drug Administration on Friday expanded the approved use of remdesivir, the infused antiviral medication from Gilead Sciences that has been widely used for hospitalized Covid patients since the early days the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Three Tiny Islands Have Borne the Brunt of Tonga’s Tsunami
description: The sparsely populated islets of Nomuka, Mango and Fonoifua were hit by waves almost 50 feet high, a Red Cross official said.
content: Tonga, the Pacific nation that was struck by a powerful tsunami last weekend, consists of about 170 islands, some tiny, stretching out across 270,000 square miles, an area roughly the size of Texas.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Ruling on Free Speech a Victory for Florida Professors
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, January 22, 2022.
content: “The solution is simple. Stop acting like your contemporaries in Hong Kong.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Fisher
title: Why Boris Johnson May Finally Have Gone Too Far
description: Moral hypocrisy, such as lying about parties held during Britain’s lockdown, is the ultimate sin in human society, with a special power to enrage.
content: Boris Johnson, long famed for brushing off accusations of distorting, misleading or outright lying that, far from slowing his rise, seemed to only bolster his image as an incorrigible scamp, suddenly faces potential political death over the very charge to which he had seemed immune.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: The N.F.L. drops coronavirus testing requirements for unvaccinated players.
description: The change means all players — vaccinated or not — will mainly be tested if they show symptoms of Covid-19.
content: With only a few weeks left in the season, the N.F.L. and N.F.L. Players Association dropped extra testing requirements for unvaccinated players.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek and Ana Swanson
title: Rapid Inflation Fuels Debate Over What’s to Blame: Pandemic or Policy
description: The White House is emphasizing that inflation is worldwide. Economists say that’s true — but stimulus-spurred consumer buying is also to blame.
content: The price increases bedeviling consumers, businesses and policymakers worldwide have prompted a heated debate in Washington about how much of today’s rapid inflation is a result of policy choices in the United States and how much stems from global factors tied to the pandemic, like snarled supply chains.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Unusual Ice and Snow Storm Hits the Carolinas and Virginia
description: A Delta flight skidded on a runway and roads remained dangerous on Saturday as the storm brought eight inches of snow to some places.
content: A storm brought ice, snow and freezing rain across the Carolinas and parts of Virginia on Friday night and early Saturday, making travel treacherous after about a quarter of an inch of ice accumulated on roads in a region that is unaccustomed to such wintry weather.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Tyler Hicks
title: Defend Chernobyl During an Invasion? Why Bother, Some Ukrainians Ask.
description: Ukraine has initiated a defensive strategy for the Chernobyl Exclusion Zone, one of the most radioactive places on Earth, which lies on the shortest path between Russia and Ukraine’s capital, Kyiv.
content: CHERNOBYL, Ukraine — Ukrainian soldiers, Kalashnikov rifles slung over their shoulders, patrolled through a silent, snowy forest, passing homes so long abandoned that vines twirl through the broken windows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Arizona Sues to Stop Treasury From Recouping Relief Funds
description: Gov. Doug Ducey has been using federal pandemic aid to undermine school mask requirements, which Treasury said violated the law.
content: WASHINGTON — Gov. Doug Ducey of Arizona sued the Biden administration on Friday to block its efforts to claw back pandemic relief money that the state has been using to undercut mask requirements in schools.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell and Leah Askarinam
title: What Mattered This Week
description: President Biden rebooted. Democrats feuded. And Republicans watched it all with glee.
content: It was another difficult stretch for Democrats. Their voting rights bills ran into a wall in the Senate, provoking angry sniping within their own ranks. Things got so heated that House Speaker Nancy Pelosi had to remind her unruly caucus members to “be respectful” of their colleagues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sandra E. Garcia
title: Ami Colé Fills a Void In Black Beauty Products
description: After toiling in the beauty industry for years, Diarrha N’Diaye-Mbaye decided to create the products she desperately sought but could not find.
content: For years, Diarrha N’Diaye-Mbaye mixed and matched foundations and concealers to create a shade that matched her rich complexion. As much as she experimented, she mostly left beauty counters disappointed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: How to Retreat From Ukraine
description: Searching for a non-disastrous way back from American overreach.
content: One of the hardest challenges in geopolitics is figuring out how to conduct a successful retreat. We witnessed that reality last summer in Afghanistan, when the Biden administration made the correct strategic choice — cutting our losses instead of escalating to preserve a morally bankrupt status quo — but then staggered through a disastrous withdrawal that wounded his presidency and laid bare American incompetence to a watching world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Monkeys Escape After Truck Crashes on Pennsylvania Highway
description: A pickup truck with an enclosed trailer full of 100 monkeys collided with a dump truck, the police said. Four escaped and one remains missing.
content: Jamie Labar was working at the front desk at a Super 8 hotel in Montour County, Pa., on Friday when she heard that there had been a crash on the highway nearby.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Healy
title: Arizona Democrats Censure Sinema After Filibuster Vote
description: Kyrsten Sinema, a first-term Arizona senator, was rebuked by fellow Democrats in her state after her vote on the filibuster helped sink the party’s voting-rights legislation.
content: PHOENIX — A rift between Senator Kyrsten Sinema and fellow Democrats back home in Arizona deepened on Saturday as the state party formally rebuked Ms. Sinema for refusing to change the Senate’s filibuster rules to pass sweeping voting rights legislation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Schwirtz, David E. Sanger and Mark Landler
title: Britain Says Moscow Is Plotting to Install a Pro-Russian Leader in Ukraine
description: In a highly unusual public statement, backed by U.S. officials, London named the putative head of a potential puppet government but few other details.
content: KYIV — The British government said Saturday that the Kremlin was developing plans to install a pro-Russian leader in Ukraine — and had already chosen a potential candidate — as President Vladimir V. Putin weighs whether to order the Russian forces amassed on Ukraine’s border to attack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: The Designer Bringing a New Kind of Cool to Kenzo
description: Nigo, the Japanese street wear king, is joining the luxury world and taking on “the greatest challenge” of his career.
content: There was a moment, about six years ago, when Nigo realized he felt old.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and Ana Swanson
title: Biden Looks to Intel’s U.S. Investment to Buoy His China Agenda
description: The president said passage of a China competition bill was needed “for the sake of our economic competitiveness and our national security.”
content: WASHINGTON — In celebrating a $20 billion investment by Intel in a new semiconductor plant in Ohio, President Biden sought on Friday to jump-start a stalled element of his economic and national security agenda: a huge federal investment in manufacturing, research and development in technologies that China is also seeking to dominate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Shpigel
title: Nick Bosa, who missed time last week with a concussion, will play for the 49ers.
description: Bosa is one of the 49ers’ biggest stars.
content: Two of the 49ers’ best defenders, after leaving last week’s game against Dallas with injuries, will be available on Saturday night. The team announced Friday that star defensive end Nick Bosa, who missed the second half with a concussion, has been cleared to play again. He will join linebacker Fred Warner, who had sprained an ankle, in San Francisco’s stellar front seven.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: Oh, By the Way: I Had a Baby
description: The pandemic has offered some women a choice they never had before: to keep their pregnancies secret til the very end.
content: On Nov. 25, Genesis Paras announced to her family and friends over Instagram that she had a new baby girl.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley
title: Eyesore or Monument? Preservationists Fight to Save a Grain Elevator in Buffalo
description: The current owner of the Great Northern has been pushing to demolish the building — possibly the last grain elevator of its type in the world.
content: BUFFALO — At first glance, the hulking brick building on the edge of Lake Erie looks like another decaying relic of Buffalo’s once-prosperous past, an image made all the worse by an enormous gash in its exterior, the victim of this city’s raking winter winds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Tennessee Couple Says Adoption Agency Turned Them Away for Being Jewish
description: Elizabeth and Gabriel Rutan-Ram are plaintiffs in a lawsuit claiming that state funding of a child-placing agency that discriminates based on religion is unconstitutional.
content: Last year, Elizabeth and Gabriel Rutan-Ram, a Jewish couple living in Tennessee, planned to adopt a boy in Florida. But on the day they were set to begin a family-training course required in their state, an initial step in the process, the agency that had been scheduled to provide the training backed out, saying the couple did not share its Christian beliefs, a lawsuit says.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Farewell, André the Glorious
description: He liked dressing in caftans and fur, and dressing me down about my style.
content: WASHINGTON — André Leon Talley was not the easiest of friends.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Arizona sues to try to keep U.S. from clawing back relief funds.
description: WASHINGTON — Gov. Doug Ducey of Arizona sued the Biden administration on Friday to block its efforts to claw back pandemic relief money that the state has been using to undercut mask requirements in schools.
content: WASHINGTON — Gov. Doug Ducey of Arizona sued the Biden administration on Friday to block its efforts to claw back pandemic relief money that the state has been using to undercut mask requirements in schools.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: The Fugees are the latest artists to cancel shows over the pandemic.
description: A tour to recognize the 25th anniversary of a career-defining album will have to wait.
content: Pandemic woes continue to disrupt the attempts of artists to resume live performances.  Months after delaying their 25th anniversary reunion tour to early this year, The Fugees announced on Friday that the tour would be canceled altogether, saying the pandemic made performing safely too difficult. On Thursday, Adele postponed her Las Vegas residency only a day before its debut.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Coaston
title: Let’s Talk About How the N.F.L. Is Failing (While the N.B.A. Reaches New Heights)
description: The football league is down to just one Black head coach.
content: On Thursday, the Houston Texans, an N.F.L. franchise worth $3.7 billion in 2021, announced that it had interviewed Josh McCown for the role of head coach. The Texans fired their previous head coach, David Culley, on Jan. 13, after just one season. (The Texans finished 4-13.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Zucchino and Jim Huylebroek
title: ‘Why Was I Born a Girl?’ An Afghan Poem Inspires U.S. Students
description: A Zoom connection between high schoolers in Afghanistan and San Diego opens a window for mutual support.
content: KABUL — When Fariba Mohebi, an 11th grader, learned in September that most Afghan girls would not join boys returning to school under Taliban rule, she shut the door and windows to her room. Then she broke down and sobbed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: President Biden’s Economy Is Failing the Big Mac Test
description: The administration made a lot of the right economic moves in its first year, but high inflation is reason enough to postpone any celebrations.
content: Measured by the value of the wages that workers take home, which this board regards as the most important metric for assessing the health of the American economy, President Biden’s first year in office was not a very good year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles
title: What Happened (and Didn’t) When Davos Disappeared
description: For the second year in a row, the World Economic Forum’s annual in-person meeting was delayed because of the pandemic. Did anyone miss it?
content: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in the news. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophie Kasakove
title: Wildfire in Big Sur Forces Residents to Evacuate
description: A late-season blaze that started on Friday grew to 1,000 acres in the scenic region of California.
content: Over 500 residents in the Big Sur area in California were told to evacuate Friday night as a brush fire spread through the mountainous coastal region known for its winding turns and dramatic cliffs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Mydans
title: Thich Nhat Hanh on Life, War and Happiness
description: “People talk about entering nirvana, but we are already there,” said the Buddhist monk, who died on Saturday. Here is a short selection of his remarks.
content: Thich Nhat Hanh, the influential Zen master, died at 95 on Saturday in the Vietnamese city of Hue, at the temple where he lived. A prolific author, poet and teacher, he believed in what he called “engaged Buddhism,” applying Buddhist principles to social issues as well as to daily life. Here is a modest selection of his thoughts, drawn from books, speeches and published interviews.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Kornei
title: Bouncing Boulders Point to Quakes on Mars
description: A preponderance of boulder tracks on the red planet may be evidence of recent seismic activity.
content: If a rock falls on Mars, and no one is there to see it, does it leave a trace? Yes, and it’s a beautiful herringbone-like pattern, new research reveals. Scientists have now spotted thousands of tracks on the red planet created by tumbling boulders. Delicate chevron-shaped piles of Martian dust and sand frame the tracks, the team showed, and most fade over the course of a few years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Lee Myers, Keith Bradsher and Tariq Panja
title: China is staging the Winter Olympics on its own terms.
description: When the International Olympic Committee met seven years ago to choose a host for the 2022 Winter Games, China’s leader, Xi Jinping, sent a short video message that helped tip the scale in a close, controversial vote.
content: When the International Olympic Committee met seven years ago to choose a host for the 2022 Winter Games, China’s leader, Xi Jinping, sent a short video message that helped tip the scale in a close, controversial vote.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Words Read With Feeling
description: Daniel Okulitch returns to the weekend puzzle stage.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Today’s grid is the third puzzle for The Times by Daniel Okulitch, a professional opera singer and bass baritone who collaborated with Doug Peterson on a Sunday puzzle just over a month ago called “Job Sharing.” (I think that theme was prescient, and that constructing is now an official side hustle for Mr. Okulitch.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gray Beltran
title: The Pandemic Changed Everything About Work, Except the Humble Résumé
description: Résumés may be more for robots than human eyes at first, but most job seekers are still advised to distill their work history in one typewritten page.
content: Two years into a pandemic, many aspects of work have changed drastically. In that time, some people have started new jobs, Zoomed their days away and then left companies where they never even met their co-workers in person.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Cain Miller and Margot Sanger-Katz
title: On Abortion Law, the U.S. Is Unusual. Without Roe, It Would Be, Too.
description: Many rich democracies have earlier cutoffs for abortion — but allow it later for a variety of reasons. And around the world, it has been much more common to expand access than restrict it.
content: Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. said last month that the United States was an international outlier in allowing abortion more than halfway through pregnancy. That later cutoff, he said, places the United States in the company of North Korea and China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Turns of Phrase
description: Nancy Stark and Will Nediger put the cart before the horse, but we’ll get where we’re going.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Nancy Stark, a New Yorker, is a writer, lyricist and former editor of the Literary Guild book club. Will Nediger, who lives in London, Ontario, is a professional crossword constructor. This is the pair’s sixth collaboration for The New York Times. The theme popped into Ms. Stark’s head at 4 a.m. one day, as these things do; Mr. Nediger built the grid, and both wrote clues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes and Jonathan Corum
title: Charting an Omicron Infection
description: Following the course of a typical Omicron infection.
content: Following the course of a typical Omicron infection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: I Watched the Building of an Olympic Venue
description: In the past 17 months, I made five trips to a village northwest of Beijing. I was curious whether one of the Olympic venues there would be ready for the Games.
content: In the past 17 months, I made five trips to a village northwest of Beijing. I was curious whether one of the Olympic venues there would be ready for the Games.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gray Beltran
title: 3 Things to Know About Résumés
description: With so many changes to the way people work in the last few years, you might wonder how much the traditional résumé still matters, and what one should even look like.
content: With so many changes to the way people work in the last few years, you might wonder how much the traditional résumé still matters, and what one should even look like.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Axel Boada and Nailah Morgan
title: Covid Outbreak Triggers Lockdown in Hong Kong Housing Complex
description: Multiple apartment buildings were locked down and 37,000 people were ordered to undergo testing after more than 100 new cases of the Omicron variant were reported in the complex.
content: Multiple apartment buildings were locked down and 37,000 people were ordered to undergo testing after more than 100 new cases of the Omicron variant were reported in the complex.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Cott, Ang Li and Ray Whitehouse
title: Voices From the March for Life
description: Protesters at this year’s anti-abortion rally expressed excitement about a coming Supreme Court ruling that could overturn Roe v. Wade.
content: Protesters at this year’s anti-abortion rally expressed excitement about a coming Supreme Court ruling that could overturn Roe v. Wade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Storyful
title: Wildfire Forces Hundreds to Evacuate in Big Sur
description: The blaze grew to 1,000 acres, and at least 500 residents in California’s Big Sur area were ordered to evacuate.
content: The blaze grew to 1,000 acres, and at least 500 residents in California’s Big Sur area were ordered to evacuate.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Jan. 22, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Jan. 22, 2022.
content: An article on Friday about President Biden’s concession on his social safety net and climate package misidentified a senator from Alabama. He is Richard C. Shelby, not Richard J. Shelby.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tough Decisions About End-of-Life Care
description: Readers offer personal stories in response to a doctor’s guest essay about advance directives.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
